B00005JPCD|4.0|***1/2<br /><br />Two emperor penguins, Memphis (Hugh Jackman) and Norma Jean (Nicole Kidman), meet through song. This isn't unusual in their community; the penguins spend much of their childhood going to school to learn how to sing for this is the way they attract a mate. Memphis and Norma Jean's egg is held by Dad during the winter, as Mom and the other females trek to the water, to feed and bring back food for their husbands and newborns. Memphis is a little upset when his egg doesn't hatch at the same time, but Mumble soon breaks through the shell. It quickly becomes apparent Mumble is no ordinary emperor penguin; his voice can cause glass to break, but he can dance. As Mumble grows older, he earns the nickname Happy Feet (Eiljah Wood) and becomes attracted to another penguin named Gloria (Brittany Murphy). But Mumble's dancing is unusual and scares the elders (led by Hugo Weaving) and his dancing is blamed for the lack of fish. Happy Feet decides he will venture forth and find the real cause of the lack of fish, as he learns of `Aliens', from Lovelace (Robin Williams), a leader of a different breed of penguins. Soon, he discovers an abandoned outpost built by humans.<br /><br />\\"Happy Feet\\", directed by George Miller (\\"Mad Max\\", \\"Babe\\") is a surprisingly enjoyable film.<br /><br />The animation is simply stunning. Every penguin is different and appears lifelike and real. As Mumble grows older, he is the one penguin in his group who still appears young, as though his adolescence is taking longer than normal. His feathers gradually recede throughout, giving him the appearance of growing, when all of his friends have already matured. This is yet another way he stands out and is made to feel different from the rest.<br /><br />There is a lot of music in \\"Happy Feet\\" and the animators have done a great job of making the penguins appear to be actually singing. Their tongues move in their open beaks and their movements appear both penguin-like and evocative of the words they are singing. The marriage of music and animation is very effective and brought to mind \\"Moulin Rouge\\"; \\"Feet\\" uses the same sort of popular songs in an unexpected context to tell parts of the story. Memphis (Jackman), has a bit of an Elvis persona, and sings songs in that same manner. Norma Jean (Kidman) is more the chanteuse, singing 70s rock ballads to attract her mate. Gloria (Murphy) is a modern girl, in more the Pink/ Cristina Aguilera mode and sings more modern songs. As each character begins singing, the rest of the penguins around them are so overcome by the melody, they join in creating a defacto chorus, singing along, mimicking the moves, etc.<br /><br />There are a couple of really nice sequences throughout \\"Happy Feet\\". At one point, Mumble and his friends are dancing and singing and then start swimming and the sequence evolves into a choreographed Busby Berkley/ Esther Williams-esque homage, everyone begins to swim in synchronized movements, swirling in circles around other swimmers. All of this is fun to watch and the animation is simply stunning and very fluid, reminiscent of the live action footage in \\"March of the Penguins\\".<br /><br />Later, Mumble and some of his friends, the different breed of penguins with Spanish accents, are swimming through the water, trying to evade a giant leopard seal. Again, great animation because it is so fluid and believable as they dart in and under stone arches, past underwater rock formations, and through tunnels.<br /><br />It is also fun to watch Mumble dance. He lets the rhythm take over and his feet begin tapping and doing a soft shoe. Famed dancer Savion Glover actually did the dancing for Mumble and his signature style is very recognizable, lots of tapping and sliding feet back and forth. They filmed Glover actually dancing, using Motion Capture technology. When they animated Mumble, Glover's feet and movements were copied and computers were used to animate the penguin's dance steps. It is a little more complicated than that, but you get the idea.<br /><br />The voice characterizations are good, but not great. Jackman seems to have the most fun with his character, giving him a discernible feel and accent. Kidman is also good and she imbues Norma Jean with a wispy, `bombshell' like voice. Eiljah Wood is less successful as Mumble and Brittany Murphy's Gloria could have been done by any other young female actress. Her voice is very recognizable, but she does little to make the character unique.<br /><br />Robin Williams provides three voices. The first is Lovelace, the leader of the smaller breed of penguins. Slightly overweight and full of bombast, he knows his place in the world and wants to keep his kingdom intact. But he is most successful with Ramon, the leader of the five penguins who tag along with Happy Feet during his journey. Using a Spanish accent, the character is funny and provides some comic relief along the way. A third voice only makes a brief appearance.<br /><br />\\"Happy Feet\\" attempts to make a statement about the effects of the environment on these animals; the lack of fish for the penguins is causing problems and the elders naturally suspect the unusual new moves Happy Feet is making. But Happy Feet learns of strange beings, \\"aliens\\", from Lovelace and suspects they may be the cause. Shunned by his community, he sets out on a quest. Without revealing too much, examples of human influences on the penguins are shown, but the course of Happy Feet's journey is strange. He has some interactions with humans, but the end result is not convincing. All of a sudden, the mere presence of the penguin leads many humans to make sweeping, world wide environmental changes.<br /><br />In the last act, when Happy Feet comes into contact with humans, we actually see some of these people. I can't figure out if director Miller used just live action footage or if he filmed real actors and then treated it in some way. The humans appear realistic, but slightly soft, almost ghost like. It is an interesting look. But at the same time, the introduction of such realistic human elements makes \\"Happy Feet\\" resemble one of those live action Disney nature films made in the 60s and 70s, where a human scientist makes a brief appearance watching the lion cubs on the veldt.<br /><br />\\"Happy Feet\\" is an enjoyable, fun film for the whole family. Not a classic, but worth watching.tle more complicated than that, but you get the idea. <br /> <br />The voice characterizations are good, but not great. Jackman seems to have the most fun with his character, giving him a discernible feel and accent. Kidman is also good and she imbues Norma Jean with a wispy, `bombshell' like voice. Eiljah Wood is less successful as Mumble and Brittany Murphy's Gloria could have been done by any other young female actress. Her voice is very recognizable, but she does little to make the character unique. <br /> <br />Robin Williams provides three voices. The first is Lovelace, the leader of the smaller breed of penguins. Slightly overweight and full of bombast, he knows his place in the world and wants to keep his kingdom intact. But he is most successful with Ramon, the leader of the five penguins who tag along with Happy Feet during his journey. Using a Spanish accent, the character is funny and provides some comic relief along the way. A third voice only makes a brief appearance. <br /> <br />\\"Happy Feet\\" attempts to make a statement about the effects of the environment on these animals; the lack of fish for the penguins is causing problems and the elders naturally suspect the unusual new moves Happy Feet is making. But Happy Feet learns of strange beings, \\"aliens\\", from Lovelace and suspects they may be the cause. Shunned by his community, he sets out on a quest. Without revealing too much, examples of human influences on the penguins are shown, but the course of Happy Feet's journey is strange. He has some interactions with humans, but the end result is not convincing. All of a sudden, the mere presence of the penguin leads many humans to make sweeping, world wide environmental changes. <br /> <br />In the last act, when Happy Feet comes into contact with humans, we actually see some of these people. I can't figure out if director Miller used just live action footage or if he filmed real actors and then treated it in some way. The humans appear realistic, but slightly soft, almost ghost like. It is an interesting look. But at the same time, the introduction of such realistic human elements makes \\"Happy Feet\\" resemble one of those live action Disney nature films made in the 60s and 70s, where a human scientist makes a brief appearance watching the lion cubs on the veldt. <br /> <br />\\"Happy Feet\\" is an enjoyable, fun film for the whole family. Not a classic, but worth watching. <br />

B000F39MAQ|5.0|I make great use of customer's reviews when purchasing DVDs from Amazon, and I confess I got no guidance from the reviews on this product. They seemed to be split between rabidly pro-Villazon supporters, and traditionalists who don't like change. I purchased anyway, since I was interested in seeing these two young performers, Netrebko and Villazon, both of whom I have heard on CD. <br /> <br />I am so glad I did. This is a stunning performance! <br /> <br />I have the ROH/Solti/Gheorgiu DVD and I love it. I have spent hours listening to both, and I am gradually coming down more in favour of this Salzburg recording, mainly because of the performance by the two leads. I say performance deliberately, because the acting is every bit as good as the singing. The big difference between Covent Garden and Salzburg is Alfredo. Netrebko can hold her own with Gheorgiu, but Villazon is special. Thomas Hampson is fine, but this is the youngsters' show. <br /> <br />The production is not my ideal, but it works. The criticisms raised by others have some validity, but are circumstantial. Why argue about the validity of Germont's motive for breaking up the relationship; it's the fact of the break-up, and the unfairness of it, that matters. <br /> <br />Changing the period is often problematical. The sets and costumes are there to remind our lazy brains of the circumstances in which the drama unfolds, and we do need to keep in mind the circumstances of life in the period in which the opera is set, to understand mythology, witchcraft, curses, religious persecution, and, of course, the concept of honour.  <br /> <br />With this performance, you will be so enthralled with the drama and music, that criticism of the period setting becomes petty carping. <br /> <br />Buy, and enjoy! <br /> <br />

0316286850|5.0|If you're seriously into makeup or if you're curious about what it can do to transform someone's face, Kevyn Aucoin's books are The Source, hands down. He gives plenty of tips on how to achieve various looks (in this one and in Face Forward), and the results are amazing. He goes over various looks, and offers advice how to get these looks (whether you want smoky eyes or poutier lips, or you want some kind of 1950s or 1960s look, or something totally fresh and modern). He explains brow shapes, eyeliner styles, lipstick application styles, applying blush, concealer, you name it. It's a makeup bible. And on top of that he does some amazing makeovers, of unknown women and famous women. To see Lisa Marie Presley transformed into Marilyn Monroe or Julia Roberts transformed into Julie Christie ala \\"Doctor Zhivago\\" is amazing to see. And that's just the tip of the lipstick iceberg. There are a lot of other transformations, some familiar looks and some all his own creations, and they're all astounding and beautiful. He's great with showing how to play with looks that make you look like you, only better, but also he's great in making you open your eyes to new looks and combinations.   The only bad thing -- actually it's tragic -- is that Kevyn died some years ago and we'll never get anymore books from him (though A Beautiful Life is a great retrospective, too, and there's his first, The Art of Makeup). And he took a lot of the pictures in the books, so it shows what an amazing photographer he was. There'll never be another one like Mr. Aucoin, but at least there are four books showcasing his amazing and timeless magical ways with makeup.

089898890X|5.0|Like Jazz?  Don't like Jazz?  It doesn't matter. Whether you like to swing or not, this book WILL make you a better drummer and musician.  The triplet feel is almost its own dimension in drumming and every drummer should master it. Although it is targeted for bebop jazz (basically faster swing feel as far as a drummer is concerned), this book will give you plenty of exercises and ideas you can incorporate in any genre.  The exercises are great for independence and time-keeping, and offer very, very good fill and solo ideas. <br /> <br />As for aspiring jazz drummers, there is absolutely no question, GET this book.  Any jazz professor at the university level would approve and it is used widely in music schools such as Berklee and Indiana University Music School (I graduated from IU). <br /> <br />The lessons on brushes are crucial and if you have never placed your hand on a brush, here is where you should start looking.   <br /> <br />The accompanying CD is great as well and helps you to master a good swing time, listen to exercises being played, listen to compositions and play along tunes with a bassist or with a whole rhythm section.   <br />

B000002GFT|5.0|This album is a great example of Fairport Convention making a characteristically British stamp on the emerging genre of folk-rock.  It's comprised mainly of actual folk songs from the isles, but the band takes possession of each song and works it up into rocking, uptempo music that is unique compared with any American folk rock of the time.<br /><br />The album opener, \\"Come All Ye,\\" pretty much lays it out there, introducing the band members and telling the listener that the music is going to get you dancing (or at least swaying) and singing or humming.  What follows are some really progressive folk songs that range from ballads, like the exciting \\"Matty Groves\\" (which, incidentally, rocks pretty hard at the ending instrumental section), the heavy riffing of \\"Tam Lin\\" (which must have been an influence on Jethro Tull), and the tragic \\"Crazy Man Michael,\\" love songs like \\"Farewell, Farewell,\\" and a great instrumental medley.<br /><br />Musically, Sandy Denny's voice is great and the guitar work is a highlight.  They manage to deftly combine acoustic instrumentation and more trippy electric instruments, yet still stay true to the British folk music and stories that underly it all.  I'd recommend this to fans of Tull and Pentangle, but also to folk rock fans of bands like the Byrds and Dylan who are interested in stretching their horizons past American folk and blues to find rewarding folk from across the pond.  Check it out, it's cheap!
B000GRUS22|5.0|The latest Engima album A Posteriori is a natural evolution of Enigma's sounds as Michele Cretu's musical stylings mature.  Smooth and Melodic filled with soft background beats and rythmic guitar rifts that follows in the path of Delerium, Honeyroot, and Royksopp.  I can see why fans of classic enigma works would be dissapointed but i believe the course of which enigma has chosed to go is a good one.  You can only do the same thing for so long before it gets tired and old.  Every musical group that continues refines their style and sound as they go on.  Groups and artists like Pearl Jam, Bjork, Nine Inch Nails, Seal, Moby have all altered their sounds as their careers have gone on.  Sometimes change is good, other times the fans don't like it so what can you do. <br /> <br />for people who didn't like the Voyageur, you may not like A Posteriori as it is sort of a morph between earlier Enigma and Voyageur.   <br /> <br />I think michele cretu should be applauded for seeking out new avenues for his musical stylings, while they aren't the same, they certainly aren't completely different either.  Either way check out A Posteriori and decide for yourself.

Certainly that would make nearyl every audiophile Beatles fan a happy camper.  This LOVE release is a mixed bag.  While I applaud the sonics, it is hard to get past some of the combinations and mixings of these classic tunes.  I know, I know...this is for the Cirque du Soleil in Vegas.  But sometimes the sheer magnitude of mixing together two and three Beatles songs in 5.1 tends to be very tiring, sometimes leading into a cacophonous orgy of nearly unintelligible, non-musical sounds. B000002UW1|5.0|The most aptly-titled R.E.M. album, this is really, in a nutshell, the mission statement if you will of the band. Using this album as a base of comparison, a person can listen to each of its other albums and get an appropriate read of the test subject's poppiness, or its political tone, or almost whatever angle they want to look at. <br />It's their manifesto, if you will, and the album which (appropriately so) everything after would be compared to due to the fact that it is the album first widely accepted by both the college radio and pop radio communities as well as critics. <br />Starting with the songs (almost) everyone knows, \\"The One I Love\\" and \\"The End of the World As We Know It (And I Feel Fine)\\" are staples of classic modern rock, and deservedly so. Michael Stipe could really be singing the alphabet in \\"The One I Love\\" and I wish that people would get over the issue of it begin a misunderstood song. It's the MUSIC and vocal melody of it that made it great. Pete Buck's guitar in that song is likely his most memorable single lick, and the dynamics of the song (from subdued verses to screaming chorus) paved the way for a lot of later pop music by many alt acts (Nirvana in particular). <br />\\"The End of the World...\\" has admittedly devolved over the years into a frat-party favorite, but that's not R.E.M.'s fault. It remains one of the best takes on apocalypse I've ever heard. Bring it on... <br />But as per usual the hits (both real and imagined) aren't the best songs on an R.E.M. album, and they're certainly not the most important ones on Document.  <br />\\"Welcome To The Occupation\\" and \\"Disturbance At The Heron House\\", as well as \\"Oddfellows Local 151\\" and \\"Exhuming McCarthy\\" are the best examples of sociopolitical songwriting the band ever had. This is perhaps due to the fact the band became so big (and thus less on the pulse of the everyday man) on subsequent releases. These four, and in particular the first two listed, are among my personal favorites of the band's career. <br />1987 was a huge year for alternative rock, perhaps the biggest between 1976 and 1991. Key releases by many artists (U2's The Joshua Tree, INXS's Kick, 10,000 Maniacs' In My Tribe, The Replacements' Pleased To Meet Me) really pushed the genre toward the end of that decade with more energy than gathered at one point prior. <br />Document was at the center of that push, and is a must-own for not just alt. rock fans, but really anyone who studies and enjoys the development of pop music in America.
B000AYEL1A|4.0|1976's \\"A Star Is Born\\" has a rich, burnished look and the romantic duo of Barbra Streisand and Kris Kristofferson at the peak of their charismatic movie-star charms. The film--a third-time go around with a masochistic plot concerning a burnt-out male entertainer on his way out and his innocent songbird spouse just experiencing big-time fame--is pure soap, yet the handling stays fairly light and doesn't get too heavy-handed (at least until the final act). Streisand (who executive produced, and perhaps directed many sequences as well) has an extremely keen and aware sense of what her audience wants from her, and she's careful to ensure the movie is spirited with a lively pace and features some good humor. Her rapport with Kristofferson is also convincing, and the early part of their star-crossed romance is bracing, with lots of raucous show-biz business to keep things from getting too sudsy. Unfortunately the script (which Streisand concedes was added to freely and frequently) seems to lose its focus once the lovers get married, becoming mired in a necessary but glum downward spiral that isn't punctuated by much character. Barbra's Esther Hoffman goes on tour, films a TV show, argues with her husband's manager, wins a Grammy--and it's just a bushel of scenes the dialogue fails to bring together as a cohesive whole (this may be a reason why the climactic events aren't really gripping or moving the way a surefire tear-jerker would be). Much better than the film itself is Streisand's full-length commentary; Barbra gets curiously quiet during the full-blown melodrama in the movie's last half, admitting during a fight scene that \\"when it's heavy..you love it or hate it\\". She's candid and entertaining in her recollections about making the picture, the '70s clothes, and her off-screen relationship with Kristofferson, which extends to their humorous wardrobe tests and to the batch of deleted scenes. B+

B00008DDSC|5.0|Foremost, Shainburg's film is based on a short-story from Mary Gaitskill's \\"Bad Behavior\\" collection. Shainberg first made a film-short from this work. Remaining true to the original, the film was dark and concluded with the mental destruction of \\"Debby\\" (later renamed \\"Lee\\"). Shainberg states that he wanted to create the this new adaptation years ago, but could not find backing for his quirky film. Following a wave of successful feminist-films (Shainberg credits Jane Campion in particular), the director was able to return to this piece. With the guidance of Maggie Gyllenhaal (only twenty-three at the time!), the script was rewritten to empower Lee. Every word was scrutinized ... the team even had Lizzie West re-record the song \\"Chariots Rise\\" because of a single line that might detract from the overall positive message. So have no reservations about this work ... after a rigorous rewrite, \\"Secretary\\" is a feminist-film about \\"choice.\\" (Remember, Lee chooses to remain at the desk ... in this moment, she is the \\"master\\" of Grey's future. She holds his heart in her hands). From Gaitskill's gloomy eight-pages to Shainberg's lush tale, one marvels at this director's talent for adaptation!<br /><br />While many viewers focus on Lee's transformation (logically so since she narrates), this film is as much about Mr. Grey's transformation as it is hers. The wonder of this work resides in beholding two \\"sick\\" people make each other healthy. Watch how posture straightens, how facial ticks disappear, how voices become bolder, and how both Lee and Grey become more radiant as the film progresses. Compare their initial encounter with the film's final scene to confirm that they nurture each other. (This is also underscored by Shainberg's repeated use of symmetry. Note how the film's framing often creates an almost split-screen effect ... harmony resides here).<br /><br />I feel it necessary to note that this film does not imply that Grey \\"cures\\" Lee's desire for self-mutilation. Psychologically speaking, Lee simply replaces the pain she experiences from cutting with the \\"pain\\" of spanking. In this, the film remains realistic and truthful to the disease. And, one is forced to wonder ... would a life with docile Peter push Lee back to her cutting-kit and polyester dresses? What can he offer her as a substitute for her pain?<br /><br />A technical note: if you are screening \\"Secretary\\" for the first time, (or are a fan already), you will want to watch the prevalence of the color purple. In film, \\"purple\\" can signify transformation ... but is also the color of childishness (think about how often you see purple adult-clothing ... now think about how often you see purple clothing on children) ... but, one must not forget that purple is also the color of bruises. How do these all tie together? Watch how purple moves from Lee's personal-life to her work-life ... seemingly indicating a transition from silly snowglobes to hidden bruises ... from a giggling woman suffering arrested-development to a poised woman choosing a very adult lifestyle. And watch for \\"purple's\\" childish resurgence in a hideous grape-shaped ring-box presented in the basement of J.C.Penny's (you will know when you see it!)<br /><br />Shainberg's film can seem slow to the uninitiated. Conservative (read: \\"timid\\") viewers or those unaccustomed to indie films may not enjoy it. For the rest, it is deliciously tormenting! It is playful, funny, and dark. For me, its charms are uplifting. Since it is designed as a fairy-tale for adults, \\"Secretary\\" plays on the notion that \\"there is someone for everyone.\\" In a way, it is a chick-flick with a twist (and Shainberg confirms that women tend to gravitate to this film more than men ... but men can certainly enjoy it!)<br /><br />This film is a rare gem for anyone interested in the \\"softer-side\\" of SMBD, in WAY off-beat romance, or even in feminist film.eaking, Lee simply replaces the pain she experiences from cutting with the \\"pain\\" of spanking. In this, the film remains realistic and truthful to the disease. And, one is forced to wonder ... would a life with docile Peter push Lee back to her cutting-kit and polyester dresses? What can he offer her as a substitute for her pain? 0953104907|4.0|I just completed my first electric using this book. I am conservative with ratings and would like to give it a 4.5 out of five. <br /> <br />My guitar was of my own design, and a bit more complecated than the ones used as examples, but used the principles in the book. The lack of a true 5-star rating was because I felt the subject matter jumped around a little, and there were a couple of 'Huh???' moments reading the examples and instructions. For example, calculating the neck angle using the example took me several read-throughs before I 'got it', when the addition of a simple extra sentence could have made the example very clear. Another was a somewhat sparse explanation of finishing techniques. Still, using the book examples will take you there. You will need to do minor British-to-American-English translation on occasion, but that adds charm to the book. <br /> <br />Don't get me wrong, this is one of those I-would-buy-again books if I lost it! <br /> <br />The guitar came out great, by the way! I agree that you will NOT save money building your own axe, but the satisfaction derived is worth a lot more than money. As a side effect of gaining the skills explained in the book, I am now free (mentally) to sell off a few of my 'store bought' guitars, such as my Strat and Les Paul, because I know I can make my own close-copy or replacement.  <br /> <br />There is worth in doing it yourself and this book takes you on that journey.

B000GRUMPU|2.0|Here's something I never, ever say about a movie: \\"Poseidon\\" is too short. The opening shot, a fake-o special effect circle around the ship, lasts nearly 3 minutes. I don't think any sequence that follows it lasts as long.  <br />All major characters and storylines are sketched into place and the ship flipped within the first 15 minutes (and that's taking at least 100 seconds to have the Black-Eyed Peas chick sing a song). Scenes whip along so quickly and with such a sense of rush that you do, indeed, feel like you're running cuz the ship is rapidly sinking... which would be good, if you'd ever had time to care about any of the characters. <br />The acting is passable, and Josh Lucas is actually pretty good in the lead. All the stuff blowing up and the water rushing about looks good enough. None of that's the problem. <br />The problem IS, you just don't care. You don't know anything at all about any of the characters (okay, I'm exaggerating: there's a young couple that you know are in love. There.) And there's no sense of a Big Plan being executed, so you could get involved in whether it's gonna work out. Yes, somebody spits out \\"Let's head for the propeller tubes!\\" and off they go...  <br />Rush rush rush. It's not just that there's no extra time devoted to developing the characters: scenes that SHOULD be there aren't. Example (SPOILER WARNING) we learn in about twenty words of dialogue that Richard Dreyfuss' character is gay and has been dumped. Fine. We see him about to kill himself over this by jumping overboard. Fine. He sees the \\"rogue wave\\" approaching and retreats. Okay. He's the only character who lives through the first 15 minutes who actually SAW what happened to them: he never mentions it. A few minutes later, he is required, basically, to deliberately kill another character to save himself. It's rather twisted, but there is an irony there that deserves at least a pause for his suicidal character to take a moment to examine. Nada. Nope, no time for reflection, we gotta hit the next explosion shot, RUN! <br />Since it ended so quickly, I took the time to watch the \\"Making Of\\" special feature, and from the interviews, you could tell that Wolfgang Petersen thought he was doing a good job, Lucas was very excited about what they were doing, many crew members believed they were working on a film that would be cutting-edge and state-of-the-art. I'm giving them the benefit of the doubt, and have decided to assume that some idiotic producer demanded they trim the film down to an hour-and-a-half, to maximize the number of showings per day, and so, in the process, they edited this thing down to a skeleton, slicing out all the \\"fat\\" that might have made it compelling. <br />It's a true shame. Hokey though the 1972 original was, it was involving and a whole lot of fun. A solid remake using today's special effects and approach to narrative was a great idea. Who knows? Maybe now that this outline was booed off the screen, Petersen will be given the chance to go back to the editing room and re-cut us a 2 1/2 hour version that WILL be worth watching. I hope so.

B000JK8OYU|5.0|Okay, there is no way I am going to rehash what you have already read, and this review will likely disappear soon in the morass of reviews to come (there are already 127 of them inside a week of it's release), but to be sure, you have been reading reviews that touch on the history of this project, on the contents of the CD/DVD, and on the controversy we all knew it would spark the moment we learned of it.<br /><br />But let's talk about how this music makes us FEEL!  Further down you will or have read a review by a \\"professional musician\\" (and others) who take a machette to the whole concept that this album is.  I for one am a Beatles \\"purist\\".  I am also an engineer.  I know technology, I know electronics, I know systems and processes and the cutting edges of our technological growth.  But...I fixed the hole in head where the rain got in a long time ago.  Do these (so called) purists, and experts, and critics have NO imagination?  What were The Beatles all about there folks?  If you are a Beatle fan, old or new, young or aged, jaded, faded, or just born, surely you have been fixing that hole and allowing for the love and introspection and imagination that was the driving creativity of The Beatles and Sir Martin.<br /><br />Just listen to this, have fun, it is an immense undertaking and don't let the detractors sway your impulses that this is simply what the boys were all about.  \\"Love\\" is a masterpiece.  If you listen to this and just enjoy it for it's creativity and ingenuity, as well as it's perfectly polished sound, and realize that this is created from masters that are 35 to 40 years old, pieces of products that were taken from a vault, the dust blown off, and set into motion on digital engineering equipment; if you have IMAGINE-ation, and Love The Beatles for what they were, a driving force in revolutionary music, and \\"a little band that just wanted to sing about love\\", if you can just enjoy something without over-analysis, then you will truly consider this a masterpiece.<br /><br />This is NOT a cash cow pulled out just in time for Christmas shopping, this is NOT a whim designed to part you from your money (just look at the Amazon and Walmart prices of the CD), nor is it a contrivance like so many \\"best of\\" compilations.  It was a labor of love on the part of Sir George Martin, his son Giles (George declares this is his last project and he is turning the reins over to Giles), and fully blessed by Olivia Harrison (George wanted to make this and started planning it with Cirque Du Soleil before he died), Yoko Ono, Ringo Starr, and Paul McCartney, none of whom have any need for more pocket change.<br /><br />This is music that feels good!  I wish more artists had left the legacy and the creativity that The Beatles did, but they were one of a kind and this \\"soundscape\\" album is a one of a kind.  So fill the cracks that run through the door, that keep your mind from wandering where it will go because it really doesn't matter, if you're wrong, you're right!s a masterpiece. <br /> <br />This is NOT a cash cow pulled out just in time for Christmas shopping, this is NOT a whim designed to part you from your money (just look at the Amazon and Walmart prices of the CD), nor is it a contrivance like so many \\"best of\\" compilations.  It was a labor of love on the part of Sir George Martin, his son Giles (George declares this is his last project and he is turning the reins over to Giles), and fully blessed by Olivia Harrison (George wanted to make this and started planning it with Cirque Du Soleil before he died), Yoko Ono, Ringo Starr, and Paul McCartney, none of whom have any need for more pocket change. <br /> <br />This is music that feels good!  I wish more artists had left the legacy and the creativity that The Beatles did, but they were one of a kind and this \\"soundscape\\" album is a one of a kind.  So fill the cracks that run through the door, that keep your mind from wandering where it will go because it really doesn't matter, if you're wrong, you're right! <br /> <br />
B00000JPYD|5.0|Trower's departure from Procol Harum allowed him to pursue his Hendrix fixation and hone his guitar attack with precision and skill.  He finally hit paydirt in 1974 with Bridge of Sighs, a monumental record from a monumental talent.  This re-release sound as fresh and vital as if Trower recorded it yesterday.<br /><br />Using a stripped-down three piece ensemble, Trower manages to pack more intense, driving music between the grooves than seems possible -- his mastery of his instrument, his effortless leads, slides, effects, and unique sounds -- enables him to create an virtuosic otherworldly space inside his mind that is fully realized, moody, energetic, beautiful, and thrilling.<br /><br />For me the title track remains one of Trower's finest pieces of recorded music -- intense, brooding, weary, relentless, and ultimately redemptive.  Is there anyone who can hear the opening bars of that song, with its amazing and creative wash of sounds, the dragging bass line, the fat guitar, and not feel better?<br /><br />The bonus tracks find Trower's three-piece rocking out in LA in 1974 -- not essential, but coming after the studio versions, an interesting look at how these songs sound live.  Hint:  pretty darn good.

B000JBXXZ4|4.0|Alright first of all, ive been listening to Incubus for quite some time now, and they have grown on me.  At first, SCIENCE was a little bit too hard for me, then it grew on me. Make Yourself as well as Morning View were excellent and A Crow... seemed to be somewhat of a mixture of their albums... which turned out pretty good in my opinion (aside from what other fans seem to think).  Light Grenades isn't a very bad album.. you MUST listen to it a few times before you make your decision to deem it \\"garbage\\".  The first listen I was actually disapointed, however, after about three more times listening through the entire CD I realized it was great.  Sure, its no Make Yourself or even Morning View, however, it does have it's good points. <br /> <br />1. Quicksand ( 8 / 10 ) - As far as I can remember, most (if not all) of incubus' previous albums have started off with a hard rock song.  On LG, they decide to start with a slow song that seems somewhat distant at first, which really belongs in its spot as an intro.  If you really listen to the lyrics you will realize this is a beautiful song... and a perfect intro.  It leads into A Kiss perfectly. <br /> <br />2. A Kiss To Send Us Off ( 9 / 10 ) - This is one of the high points on the album. It somewhat reminds me of \\"Nice To Know You\\" off of Morning View.  Both songs have hard rock and then they are slowed down (especially the last verse of A Kiss). The lyrics are good, and the guitar work displayed by Mike is exceptional.  Just give this song a chance, you may not like it at first, but it will definitely grow on you. <br /> <br />3. Dig ( 9 / 10 ) - Dig is an excellent song that could possibly see some time on the radio.  Listen to the lyrics, they are great. Possibly my favorite song on the album. <br /> <br />4. Anna Molly ( 9 / 10 ) - The first single off the cd, Anna Molly, is the only song (other than Dig) that will probably be on the radio.  Good lyrics, great guitar. <br /> <br />5. Love Hurts ( 6 / 10 ) - The first time I heard this song I loved it.  That was until I paid attention to the lyrics. Sure, the guitars good, but the lyrics aren't really up to par, an example is, \\"Love hurts but sometimes its a good hurt\\". I know what you mean by this, Brandon, but I don't really think this should have been part of the chorus, it makes the song sound somewhat corny. <br /> <br />6. Light Grenades ( 9 / 10 ) - Any fan of S.C.I.E.N.C.E should enjoy this song.  Very fast paced song. <br /> <br />7. Earth To Bella Part I ( 7 / 10 ) - Aside from what others think, I don't really have a problem with this song.  It starts off pretty good then the guitar just being smacked is pretty unpredictable.. but its not that bad after a few listens. <br /> <br />8. Oil and Water ( 8 / 10 ) - Another good song on the album.. didn't like it that much at first but it grew on me. Love the lyrics. <br /> <br />9. Diamonds and Coal ( 5 / 10 ) - In my opinion, one of, if not, the worst song on the album. Reminds me of some elevator-type beat. <br /> <br />10. Rogues ( 8 / 10 ) - Another quick song on the album, great drum work by Jose. Love Brandon's voice in this. <br /> <br />11. Paper Shoes ( 6 / 10 ) - This song isn't bad.. it just annoys me.  I really don't know why.. its just.. bleh. <br /> <br />12. Pendulous Threads ( 7 / 10 ) - Didn't listen to this song all that much.. it isn't THAT bad.. perhaps it will grow on me. <br /> <br />13. Earth to Bella II ( 5 / 10 ) - Good for an outro i guess.. but it really makes the other Earth to Bella look bad. <br /> <br />Overall, its a pretty good album. The lyrics are pretty deep.  The earth to bella's im sure have some more meaning than i could pull out of them. One thing I didn't like very much was the lack of DJ Kilmore.  He seemed like he wasn't even in, or didnt play a very big role, in any of the songs. Like I said before, its no Make Yourself or Morning View, but a good album.
0393327345|5.0|I like to read things that come from Chuck Palahniuk's mind. The result could be good (Diary) or bad (Invisible Monsters); sometimes you never know. What you do know is that the story will likely be something you could never come up with on your own. That is not to say that they are mystery novels and the suspense is imaginative. Though Palahniuk's suspense is certainly imaginative, his stories follow no mold I have seen before.  <br /> <br />Chuck Palahniuk is probably just what you would expect him to be like, should you have an opportunity to see him. I saw him give a speech a few years ago, and he was just as I expected. He said that when he writes books he tends to pick one music album to listen to while he writes. One album. For Fight Club, he said he listened to The Downward Spiral by Nine Inch Nails. Again, probably just as you would have expected. Neat guy. Wonderful speaker. Incredibly interesting writer.  <br /> <br />I have seen the movie adaptation for Fight Club. I love the movie and am always impressed with the parts played by Brad Pitt and Ed Norton, Jr. I was not hesitant, but rather curious to read the book. Normally I figure a person will prefer whichever version they experience first. I wasn't reading the book in hopes that it would be better than the movie since as they say, \\"the book is always better.\\" I wanted to see this story on paper through Palahniuk's eyes and with his words rather than a Hollywood adaptation of both.  <br /> <br />I found exactly what I had hoped for. The foundation was the same as the movie, but the writing was a little rougher around the edges. It was rough because it was not written to appeal to a broader audience like the movie script was, and it was rough because it was his first book. Like many authors, Palahniuk's writing has become...smoother, for lack of a better term, with each book he has written. Please do not interpret that as a complaint with the book or a negative comment, it is only an observation. If anything, it made the book better as it was more fitting with the feel of the story.  <br /> <br />I have seen the movie. Any potential, big plot-twist at the end of the story, if one existed....would not have been a surprise reading the book. I did not care. I wasn't reading the book for the story to be new again. I was only interested in seeing the story a different way, which I was able to do. Fight Club isn't the best book I have ever read, nor is it one of my favorites, but I am glad I took the time to read it. And I recommend it. You have no excuses, it's short.  <br />

0345475674|4.0|'Pompeii' is a highly readable historical mystery set in Roman Pompeii in 79 C.E. just before the 'you know what' happens. Robert Harris has an eye for historical detail and can spin a good yarn. The reader of Pompeii learns a bit about Roman aqueducts, the Roman empire and, of course, volcanoes.<br /><br />The protagonist, Marcus Attilius Primus, is the new 'aquarius' sent out from Rome to take over the care and maintenance of the Aqua Augusta, the immense aqueduct that served the Bay of Naples area. Figure out just what did happen to the former aquarius, why the water has dried up, and how did a former slave become the (apparently) richest, most powerful man in Pompeii. Meet Pliny the Elder along the way.<br /><br />A fun read. Highly recommended for lovers of water, volcanoes, and the Roman Empire.
0802130208|5.0|What can I say about this book that will accurately surmise the story and its habitual moments of hilarity?  Well, it's not that easy.  The book is not exactly based on a clearly defined story line but rather on the interactions and failed enterprises of some very colorful characters in New Orleans.  The story of these individuals (individuals one might refer to as dolts, hence the use of the word \\"dunces\\" in the title), is spearheaded by one Ignatius J. Reilly.  At thirty-three Ignatius is stuck in prepubescence, can't keep a job to save his life, and suffers from an impassioned antipathy for modernity.  He is taunted through correspondence by an associate named Myrna Minkoff, who is 'socially loose' and condemns Ignatius - with unparallel buffoonery - for not doing anything with his life.  The rest of the characters Toole presents us with are equally farcical and suffer from that nincompoop condition that plague Ignatius and Myrna.<br /><br />But Ignatius and Myrna are only two of the characters you will encounter in this great book.  To meet the rest of the confederacy you must read the story.

After a 5-year mission in outer space, the world's greatest superhero (Brandon Routh) returns to Earth and learns that the world especially star journalist Lois Lane (Kate Bosworth) has moved on without him. When arch nemesis Lex Luthor (Kevin Spacey) resurfaces with a new sinister plot, Superman must put his troubles behind to protect the countless lives that lost faith in him. \\"Superman Returns\\" is an absolute joy to watch. Director Brian Singer has done an amazing job with the X-Men franchise and his latest comic book adaptation truly shines. \\"Superman Returns\\" pays tribute to the original 1978 Richard Donner feature film with the same 3-D opening titles and memorable music score. The movie features an entertaining storyline, outstanding special effects, rousing action sequences and fine performances by Kevin Spacey, Kate Bosworth and newcomer Brandon Routh.<br /><br />If you're a Superman fan or just looking for a solid good time then \\"Superman Returns\\" 2-Disc Special Edition is a worthy purchase. The 3-hour summer spectacle is presented in its theatrical 2.35:1 anamorphic widescreen format. The DVD has a sharp video transfer with bright colors and good resolution. Its 5.1 Dolby Digital sound definitely gets the job done. The DVD also features an extensive \\"The Making of Superman Returns\\" documentary, deleted and extended scenes, theatrical trailers and \\"Resurrecting Jor-El\\" FX featurette. Overall, \\"Superman Returns\\" gets a \\"B+\\".
B00005B36H|5.0|This is hands-down THE masterpiece of 2001, and, in my opinion, the best album of the early 21st century. It's not just music, the entire album and the artwork it comes with is truly an experience - the perfect realization of a dedicated and persistent vision.<br /><br />The music is exquisite. Every song is not just a journey in-and-of-itself, but they all culminate into a perfectly paced, wondrously executed singular pulse that is Lateralus. The album cover is translucent and flips open to reveal the different layers of the human body, including a spiritual layer representing vrajna, the transcendental wisdom of enlightenment or union with the divine. Partially obscured in the brain matter on the final layer is the word \\"God.\\" The artwork was done by artist Alex Grey.<br /><br />The lyrics and musical progressions of the songs on the album also encompass this theme of deep enlightenment, but, thanks to Maynard's genius, can also be interpreted very subjectively. \\"The Grudge\\" is thematically about, well, a grudge, or misguided attempts at holding one, with the significance of Saturn being that which rules over a negative person (the Saturnist). The lyrics give the advice to `let go' of a `fated anchor' before Saturn \\"consumes you.\\" Hence, let go of the grudge before it drags you down. \\"Eon Blue Apocalypse\\" acts as a placid introduction to \\"The Patient,\\" a song about waiting and `giving blood' for the `damaged and broken' but reaping rewards (i.e., self-healing) in the process. As is the case with many Tool songs, the meaning of \\"Schism,\\" the album's 5th track which is preceded by appropriately titled \\"Mantra,\\" is heavily debated by the fans. The most widely accepted translation is that the song deals with the differences between man and woman and their relationship. This is believed to be backed by the song's video, which features two humanoid creatures, which appear to be a male and a female.  \\"Parabol\\" and \\"Parabola,\\" the album's 6th and 7th tracks, act together as the central movement in Lateralus. While there is also a large debate in the Tool community about this song's ultimate meaning, it can all be boiled down thematically to the purity of an enlightening experience - whether it is birth, sex, love or possibly even the gift of life itself. \\"Ticks and Leeches,\\" the album's angriest track, is essentially about those who seek only to live off of others. Admittedly, this song seems a pariah when one tries to fit it into the album's theme. It seems to feed into anger, much the subjects of the song feed off others. Perhaps it another glimpse into the role of anger in the process of ultimate enlightenment, or perhaps it is just an angry side-step for the band. \\"Lateralus\\" is where the album's theme finally culminates and is fully explored. This song if crafted with an unprecedented attention the detail and is regarded by many as the band's deepest, most transcending song. Maynard James Keenan's vocals during the first few minutes of Lateralus form a Fibonacci sequence. The number of syllables progress to the sixth step, then back down to the first step; up to the seventh step, and then back to the fourth step. The Fibonacci sequence shares a relationship with Phi, the golden ratio. The golden ratio is used to describe spirals, which are mentioned several times in the lyrics. It all leads to the final, climactic verse: `With my feet upon the ground, I lose myself between the sounds and open wide to suck it in. I feel it move across my skin. I'm reaching up and reaching out. I'm reaching for the random or whatever will bewilder me, whatever will bewilder me. And following our will and wind, we may just go where no one's been. We'll ride the spiral to the end and may just go where no one's been. Spiral out. Keep going, going...' may be interpreted as reaching a higher state of consciousness, or otherwise bettering oneself in a profound way. \\"Disposition\\" is a terse, but beautiful song about acceptance and forgiveness, which fades into the album's final thematic anthem: \\"Reflection.\\" This song reiterates Tool's consistant message throughout this other albums: our need to evolve and realize our full potential as beings of conscious thought. `Crucify ego before it's far too late to leave behind this place, so negative and blind and cynical.' After this 11 minute epic finally releases, we are lead into a pulsing instrumental, \\"Triad,\\" whose names refers to the mystical number \\"3\\" in many of the world religions, and emphasizes the album's thematic connection to vrajna. The album's final track,  \\"Faaip de Oiad\\" is a recording of a call from a 1997 conversation on Art Bell's radio program Coast to Coast AM. The caller, in a frantic tone, claimed to have been previously employed at Area 51 and stated that the true nature of aliens were that of \\"extra-dimensional beings\\" that have infiltrated the military establishment and plan to destroy the world's large population centers to more easily control the remaining humans. The broadcast was cut short however, when their transmitter failed but Art Bell returned on the air with the use of a back up link system. Supposedly, the same caller called back some weeks later and claimed it was a hoax. \\"Faaip de Oiad\\" is Enochian for \\"the voice of God.\\"<br /><br />It is easy to see why this album is held in such high regard. It is not just an auditory experience, it is truly something enlightening in its own regard - a homage to the true potential of music (yes, even `rock' music), and an exploration into ultimate human consciousness and enlightenment. No matter what type of music you like, this album is a MUST for anyone who appreciates true artistic and creative vision, and, not mention, incredibly arranged and composed music.h fades into the album's final thematic anthem: \\"Reflection.\\" This song reiterates Tool's consistant message throughout this other albums: our need to evolve and realize our full potential as beings of conscious thought. `Crucify ego before it's far too late to leave behind this place, so negative and blind and cynical.' After this 11 minute epic finally releases, we are lead into a pulsing instrumental, \\"Triad,\\" whose names refers to the mystical number \\"3\\" in many of the world religions, and emphasizes the album's thematic connection to vrajna. The album's final track,  \\"Faaip de Oiad\\" is a recording of a call from a 1997 conversation on Art Bell's radio program Coast to Coast AM. The caller, in a frantic tone, claimed to have been previously employed at Area 51 and stated that the true nature of aliens were that of \\"extra-dimensional beings\\" that have infiltrated the military establishment and plan to destroy the world's large population centers to more easily control the remaining humans. The broadcast was cut short however, when their transmitter failed but Art Bell returned on the air with the use of a back up link system. Supposedly, the same caller called back some weeks later and claimed it was a hoax. \\"Faaip de Oiad\\" is Enochian for \\"the voice of God.\\" <br /> <br />It is easy to see why this album is held in such high regard. B000ICL3KG|5.0|Most Americans have heard of \\"that Al Gore documentary.\\" Well here it is, AN INCONVENIENT TRUTH.<br /><br />If you've followed U.S. politics at all over the past 20 years, you know that Al Gore is the environmental poster-boy thanks to his take on global warming and other green issues. It wouldn't be difficult to surmise that his presidential run may have been hamstrung by this very topic. Big Business doesn't usually sit in the environmentally friendly arena, and Big Business most certainly contributes (via backdoors) to candidates financial checking accounts.<br /><br />For better or worse, Al Gore lost his presidential bid. The \\"better\\" aspect is that Al was then free to do whatever he liked with his life. He wouldn't be in the spotlight or battling legislators. So what did he do? He went back to his roots.<br /><br />An Inconvenient Truth, a lecture/slide-show Gore has probably given hundreds of times, would otherwise be pushed aside by politicians as an attack on industry if it were done by anyone else. But Gore's been on the inside. His science is strong and his data backed by nearly every scientist on the planet (note the word \\"nearly\\", as some simply do not agree, but the overwhelming majority - 90% or higher - do). This is an important fact, as scientists follow data, not personal beliefs or the S&P 500.<br /><br />The entire documentary is about global warming and how amazingly ignorant or apathetic the world has become because of our reliance on outdated technology, our increasing population, and our refusal to change. The outdated technology is mostly about automobiles, since they produce the most greenhouse gas emissions. The fact that the world's population has gotten out of control can be seen simply by looking at various countries' census reports and then comparing them to agricultural and water needs. Our refusal to change is focused on throughout the film thanks to our reliance on oil, coal, and other non-replenishables.<br /><br />Al Gore has to be commended for doing such a great job on this documentary. He is the center of it, but he so effortlessly takes the focus off of himself and puts it on these hot-button topics that it's easy to forget we're learning material from a former vice-president. That was truly astonishing.<br /><br />Gore's passion for the global warming issues are admirable and most will probably be thankful that he's out there pushing this topic, trying to bend the ear of every person he possibly can. Make no doubt about it, he's making money off this project, too. But viewers would probably rather see someone as important as Gore making money this way rather than working for Enron or Exxon/Mobil.l Gore has to be commended for doing such a great job on this documentary. B00007KWHN|5.0|With the exception of Tony Kaye, this album was the beginning for Yes' classic lineup, which was Jon Anderson, Steve Howe, Chris Squire (the best bassist I've ever heard!), and Bill Bruford (and Rick Wakeman who would replace Tony on the keyboards on the next album). While a few lineup changes in the near future didn't really cause any severe problems (and that includes even when Jon was replaced), but this will always remain the lineup they're best known for. Many fans believe that The Yes Album was their first masterpiece. Well, I can't say for sure, since I also liked their debut, and I have yet to hear Time And A Word. But this album is great nonetheless, and definitely a masterpiece. The album opens up with Yours Is No Disgrace. While it's a bit too repetitive for my tastes, and while I personally don't think it can hold its own to future Yes album openers like Close To The Edge and The Gates of Delirium, it's still an awesome song, with great, obscure lyrics, and long soundscapes. I really don't care for the acoustic instrumental Clap; it's just Steve showcasing his talent on the acoustic guitar. However, the album really picks up Starship Trooper. It's easily my favorite off the album and one of my all-time favorite Yes songs. It's frantic, relaxing, spacy, [place adjective hear], everything I want in a Yes song. Then comes I've Seen All Good People, which is my 2nd favorite song off the album. It's also one of their most popular songs, right up there with Roundabout and Owner of A Lonely Heart. Tony Kaye (keyboards) gets to really shine here, especially near the end when his organ effect builds and builds until the whole song slowly fades out. Venture is mostly a keyboard song, dominated by Tony. While I think Rick Wakeman, who would come in after this album, was far superior (and you'd probably agree with me), he's still good. It's just not something I want to listen to every day like the others. Prepetual Change makes up for that song though. It's the 3rd best off the CD, as well as the jazziest and most melodic, and Jon's best peformance on the album. Like I've Seen All Good People, it keeps playing until it finally fades out. Thr lyrics are also great and fasinating.<br /><br />My only real complaint is that the production is awfully dry. I mean really, really dry. Sometimes I have to listen real hard to hear an instrument. But still, that complaint is very minor. I would also like to compliment Chris' stellar bass work (which is also great on all the other albums). I, as a bassist with above average skill, can tell you that this stuff is VERY hard to play. He's my favorite member of the band and my favorite bassist of all time. So buy this album if you're a Yes fan, or if you're looking for some great progressive rock. Though I wouldn't recommend it for newbies (that's what Close To The Edge is for).best off the CD, as well as the jazziest and most melodic, and Jon's best peformance on the album. B000JBXXZ4|5.0|i really didn't want to set the bar to high on my expectations of this album, i hate to be dissapointed. but it was hard, their last album aclotm was a great blend of the guitar of the heroics of fungus amongus mixed with the harder and progressive rock of make yourself and science, m.v. to a lesser extent, but yet fresh sounding in arrangement and production. but hearing the ep from alive at red rocks and especially the instrumental tracks they contributed to the halo 2 soundtrack, i couldn't help but be anxious. well, they did it, they pushed their sound forward. there's creativity on here (different sounds and instruments, they don't just defer to scratching and samples to accompany the guitar bass & drum, which is nice for a change, not that the other way was bad), there's some harder riffs than appeared on the last few records, there's some songs with a more acoustic feel, and then the songs that blend everything and really sound fresh. i know what rock music for the most part has sounded like in 2006, and it hasn't been very good. for all the bands that have tried to duplicate incubus' sound over the years none have even come close to reproducing the level of creativity and skill that these guys play with. quick song by song: <br /> <br />quicksand: just an intro song to peak your curiosity i believe, and it works. i think its to slow you down so the first tempo change hits you that much harder in the next song. 7/10 <br />kiss to send us off: this is a great tune, sounds diff. than anything they've done, not way different but enough to give some respect, love the riffs, and the breakdown. 10/10 <br />dig: its a relaxing tune for the most part, the lyrics certainly make a lot of sense. musically its nice to see these songs because incubus puts every bit as much musicality into these tunes as the do the more epic/louder songs. 8/10 <br />anna molly: this song could have been on a aclotm, but thats not a bad thing, its the same band after all, but i love the arrangement, its tight,  some songs have a looser feel but this one pounds from beginning to end. 9/10 <br />love hurts: first off, if you've been following incubus for a while you have to expect a song or two like this on every album (echo, southern girl, monuments and melodies, etc.) i like the lyrics, i like the music. incubus are a complete band, they can write a toned down track like this and have it sound great, and not every song needs lyrics that it takes you awhile to figure out, this is just straitforward. 7/10 <br />light grenades: love it, it takes you back to old days to an extent, but its great when they speed things up because mike is such a great guitarist you just want to hear what he'll come up with for something like that. (the rest of the band is up to the task as well) its loud and fast and should please old and new fans. 10/10 <br />earth to bella pt.1: on here the critism confuses me a lot. this is for one a cool song, and two its different than any other they've written. i want these guys being as creative as they feel and when i hear this track it seems like someone got an idea and they just did it. and i think it sounds great, if you buy the new all american rejects or panic at the disco album they won't have any tracks like this so if you can't get outside the verse chorus verse structure for a track or two consider those. (and for those who have the sarcasm meter turned off, i do not own those discs, you know, because they're boring) 8/10 <br />oil and water: this is a great track, again combining some of the softer and louder aspects of the band in a very sucessful way, nothing to really fault in this song, you can tell they have a great relationship with the producer. 9/10 <br />diamonds and coal: its a pretty straitforward song, definately the most mainstream sounding rock song on the record. and no its not a crime to make a song that could be played on pop radio, its still a great song, its my least favorite as i like tracks that sound like signature incubus but this is a band thats been together a long time and they try different things, some of it sounds crazy and strange and some of it sounds really normal, these guys can write any kind of song their is. 6/10 <br />rogues: another great rocker, again signature incubus but with some new things we haven't heard before, i love how the verses kick, brandon really seems to be attacking these lyrics. 10/10 <br />paper shoes: its like the slow song that they really wanted to try some different things, (kind of like talk shows on mute, the idea i mean not neccesarily the sound), i like it for what it is. 7/10 <br />pendulous threads: i don't what inspired them to write this song or to put in the long intro but i couldn't be happier that they did, this song again sounds very fresh and new and is an exciting listen. not sure my favorite song on the record right now but this is top three. kind of sounds like the mars volta with the sounds and the guitar solos, but thats not a knock as incubus was around first, just trying to describe the sound. 10/10 <br />earth to bella pt.2: its cool that they made these songs and i'm glad they're on here and not just recored and lost. if incubus wants to make a whole album of songs like these i'll happily pick it up. 8/10 <br /> <br />to summarize, all the members are now pushing 30, to still be so creative and take elements of all their previous and put out something new on the same level of quality is amazing. this band is still in their creative prime and i hope it stays that way.

B0000DJZA5|3.0|The GET BACK album is one of the most legendary unreleased albums in the history of rock and roll. Recorded in Janaury 1969, it sat on the shelf for over a year before being salvaged and reworked by legendary producer Phil Spector. The result, LET IT BE, was finally released in May 1970 shortly after the news that the group had split hit the headlines.    For many years, fans have been clamoring for the original GET BACK to be finally released. Shortly before the death of George Harrison, rumors that Apple was finally going to release GET BACK began to spread. Instead we got this.    LET IT BE...NAKED is a stripped down, retro-revisionist album that allegedly presents what the Beatles (read Paul McCartney) originally wanted LET IT BE to be. Its release, timed perfectly with the publicity surrounding Phil Spector's murder arrest, is of course a slap in the face to Spector. Not only are Spector's heavy arrangements ripped off of \\"Across the Universe\\" and \\"I Me Mine,\\" but Spector himself is ripped off by the fact that his original edits are left untouched.    The album is not totally without merit, however. \\"Across the Universe\\" is without a doubt the set's highpoint.     Beyond \\"Across the Universe,\\" however, LET IT BE...NAKED has nothing new or exciting to offer. \\"Get Back\\" has the ending missing, which makes it sound incomplete. Tracks like \\"Let It Be\\" and \\"The Long and Winding Road\\" are far inferior to the ones on the original album, while \\"Two of Us\\" and \\"One After 909\\" are the same and add nothing new.    All in all, this album is a disappointment.

To my surprize I found dozens of HD DVD movies at Wal-Mart for 19.99 including this one.  With shipping I paid over $32.  I WILL NOT be ordering DVD's, or CD's from this site again!  Shame on you Amazon!

B000JJS8TM|5.0|I was 14 when the Beatles were on Ed Sullivan, so I know these songs inside and out.  I'm a bass player, and I've played some of these songs forever in bar bands.  So this project almost seems like sacrilege to me. I should hate this, and yet...It's brilliant!      You need to spend the extra $5.00 or whatever to get the audio DVD.  The sound quality is miraculous.  Somehow George and Giles Martin digitally scrubbed these 40 year-old recordings until they sound like they were recorded last week.  There's a spot in \\"Hey Jude\\" in the \\"na na na na \\" chorus at the end, where the Martins take out all the instruments but the percussion, then after a few bars, they drop in Paul McCartney's lovely bass line for 4 bars.  I'd never even heard it in the original mix.  That moment alone was worth the price of admission for me.      Somebody has probably already mentioned this in a review here, but I'll say it too:  If they remastered the whole damned Beatles catalog to this level of sound quality, I'd buy them all again.       Edit, Nov. 10, 2010:  They did, and I did!

The one person who hasn't truly moved on however, is Lex Luthor (Kevin Spacey) who has his own diabolical plans, including one that Superman might not be able to stop.  Routh is good, Spacey is a hoot, Bosworth is a bit miscast, and the rest of the cast, including James Marsden, Frank Langella, Parker Posey, Kal Penn, and Sam Huntington, are quite good.  The story, crafted by Singer and his X2: X-Men United cohorts Michael Dougherty and Dan Harris, is a bit predictable but offers some nice surprises while paying homage to Richard Donner's 1978 original film, and unlike many comic book films, has actual heart to it.  The special effects are spectacular, and as a whole the film is better than I had anticipated.  It doesn't achieve what the original Superman, X2, Spider-Man 2, or Batman Begins does, but it's pretty close nevertheless.

You get perhaps two minutes of \\"life on the reservation\\" as a group of Navajo Indians are brought in for special training. Their language is so complex that the army figures it will form the basis of an unbreakable code, one they can use without fear of being understood. There's a catch of course, as there are with all such codes - you can't let the key get into the enemy's hands. In this case, it means one of the Code Talkers can never be captured.<br /><br />Cage is a soldier assigned to protect one of these Navajos - Ben Yahzee (played by Adam Beach). He feels silly being a nurse-maid but also torn knowing that he might have to kill this man in cold blood. Other soldiers are less shy about how they feel. They actively look down on the Navajos as being inferior, and one even attacks him, claiming he could kill him because he \\"looks like a Jap\\".<br /><br />Directed by John Woo, you need to realize right up front that this isn't going to be a calm, collected view of war's emotional drama. There is a lot of Rambo-like blasting, a lot of nonsensical fighting without taking cover. Cage is not only stoical about his task - he is almost wooden in his lack of emotion.<br /><br />It's also a shame, for a movie which is all about the skill of the Navajos - that they end up being a side line in the story. I would have loved more introductory material, to introduce how the Navajos were living on their reservation, how they were treated there. I would have liked to see how they made their decisions to defend their country despite that prejudice. I would also have liked to see how they were treated when they returned. That would have really made it more a story about \\"The Navajo Code Talkers\\" and less about \\"Nicholas Cage and his Sidekick Visit Japan\\".<br /><br />I also couldn't understand *why* the code talkers were doing some of the tasks they were doing. Let's say they were radioing the position of the enemy, so the ships could fire on them. Why was this location a secret? Didn't the enemy know where their own troops were? It wasn't like they were radioing in \\"We are about to sneak from position X to position Y\\".<br /><br />Still, you can look at it from the point of view that at least SOMETHING was said about this most valuable contribution of the Navajos. Many people had no idea that the code talkers existed, and once they learned the basics from the movie, they went on to learn more on their own.the position of the enemy, so the ships could fire on them. Why was this location a secret? Didn't the enemy know where their own troops were? It wasn't like they were radioing in \\"We are about to sneak from position X to position Y\\".<br /><br />Still, you can look at it from the point of view that at least SOMETHING was said about this most valuable contribution of the Navajos. Many people had no idea that the code talkers existed, and once they learned the basics from the movie, they went on to learn more on their own.

I'm afraid long-time fans will be disappointed because I don't think \\"Shutter Island\\" works on a number of levels. Readability is a problem - it feels like Lehane had a hard time with this. The plot jerks along with numerous stretches where nothing much happens. None of the characters, including the protagonist, is very interesting, and the final plot revelation, instead of providing the heart-pounding \\"Oh my God!\\" moment the author expects, instead evokes more of a shrug and a \\"glad it's over\\" feeling. I almost think Lehane was trying to write a 21st century \\"One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest\\" but this doesn't even come close. There are a million better books vying for your attention.

B000IJ79WU|4.0|I have been a big fan of the Christopher Reeve Superman movies for the longest time. Every moment in them, even in the two later sequels that lacked always had a special place with me and my childhood. Everyone knows the story of what happend with Richard Donner and why he was removed from the directors seat. But no one expected this version to actually see the light of day. Was it worth the wait? That's a matter of opinion but I thought it was really great.<br /><br />The reviews are pretty mixed and for good reason. Those in love with the regular version of Superman II may not like some of the changes in this film as it does lack the comedy and sight gags that the original version had but if you look at this film without referencing the regular version, its pretty good.<br /><br />Moments like Lois jumping out of a window at the Daily Planet and the gun shot moment in the hotel at Niagra Falls were nice additions. As well as some of the opening moments and the conclusion of the movie which differed greatly from what we saw previously. All nice changes and work well.<br /><br />I for one was glad to see things such as the Cellophane S and the KFC worker telling the guy she had his change, removed from the movie. While fun situations they just didn't seem to fit into the whole nature of the film in it's original intention. Which wasn't to be a comedy flick but a good continuation to the first film. Marlon Brando was a nice addition actually. Im not a big fan of his generally but his moments really added something that the other didn't. Clark yelling at his father for help and shouting that he loves Lois really made this all more believable. There was a lot of nice touches that really belonged in the series and now we finally get to see the original vision for the first time.<br /><br />Some omitions I was a bit sad to see go. I did love the moment where Lois jumps into the river to prove that Clark was Superman. The whole rescue scene was fun. And I was sad to see a lot of the Idaho scenes were cut out like the little boy being abused by Zod. Some moments seemed to be resolved too quickly like the confrontation with the county police and their car. It was a nice touch in Lesters version with the siren being ripped off. Here it just seemed to be over passed to fast.<br /><br />A real problem is the movie can seem to drag on at points. Lex learning about the villans is cool to see and all but unneccesary as we really know enough about them that its not really needed for the audience. Some of his playing with the crystals too seemed to drag on for a bit. So be prepared for some long periods of talking and story building but the movie is still under 2 hours so nothing that really over the top.<br /><br />For the most part I would say this was pretty good and definitely a version I would have loved had it been what we originaly saw. You have to go in with a grain of salt here as first of all not all of the footage was recovered and more importantly we are all so familiar with the version of the movie we did get originally that its hard to just forget it and the moments we loved in it. If this had been the version we saw first we would have loved this just as much. In a way I do wish that there could be a way to mix and match the two versions. There were some things I loved that were left out of this one but so much that I thought was great in this one.<br /><br />Overall I say definitely get this one. If you are a fan of the Superman films this is a must have. Your expectations shouldn't be so high that this won't meet them, but do go in with the thought that this is using lost footage from 1980 that has to be put upon us after such a long time of seeing the other. If you see this as a fresh and new follow up to the first, you will truly see why this was so much fun.<br /><br />Its up to you though when all is said and done. If you are expecting the comedy and slapstick moments of the orginal as well as everything you remember justwith some additions, then you may not like this. If you want to see the original vision and a brand new alternative vision of what the follow up to the first could have or should have been (depending on your opinon of it) then I say its more then worth it. You can never have too much Superman in your DVD collections. And you can also buy the Superman II Deluxe edition if you want the regular as you remember it. But I do think people are missing out if they don't check this out too. Its pretty good and I don't think people will regret checking it out.ant to see the original vision and a brand new alternative vision of what the follow up to the first could have or should have been (depending on your opinon of it) then I say its more then worth it. You can never have too much Superman in your DVD collections. And you can also buy the Superman II Deluxe edition if you want the regular as you remember it. But I do think people are missing out if they don't check this out too. Its pretty good and I don't think people will regret checking it out.

B000JK8OYU|3.0|The Beatles were obviously pioneers. Apart from writing terrific songs that have withstood decay for over 40 years, they increasingly mastered creating the ultimate atmosphere to embed their songs in. Voicings, instrumentations, arrangements, production, track order, everything added to the perfection of the song itself or the album as a whole. In this process The Beatles were, in my opinion, revolutionary and refreshing. <br /> <br />Love, however, isn't. It is a well crafted remix of strong songs, but it lacks the innovativity to really transform classics into new classics. Knowing the originals doesn't help, on the contrary. It emphasizes how incredible the original songs were (and are), and how amazing these twentysomethings were in the 60's. By craftily polishing the dust off these tracks in an effort to refresh it, it seems like the freshness has been wiped of as well. <br /> <br />True, by mixing up different (parts of) songs and offering them in surprising contexts, the original compositions are even more appreciated, but that was also (and better) the case on the three Anthology CD's.  <br /> <br />For people who are already familiar with the Beatles, my advice would therefore be to acquire the Anthology-CD's and leave 'Love' for those new to the Beatles. As a springboard to the originals, of course ;-) <br /> <br />Bart (29)

B00005R1N3|2.0|Black Christmas has creepy suspense, yeah. Great buildup, sure. And those phone calls? Freaking weird.  <br /> <br />But it does not have cohesion. Or closure. A movie doesn't need those things to be good, but their absence in Black Christmas wrecks the whole ship. All that suspense and those phone-melting calls are pretty good on their own, but the anticipation of figuring out \\"But who's doing it...and WHY?\\"  is the driving force behind the movie. And what they actually led up to? Pllllllbbbtttttt. Totally unsatisfying.  <br /> <br />It's fitting that this movie is set around the holidays, because watching it is just like opening a bunch of cool presents on Christmas morning, saving the best wrapped one for last, and then ripping it up only to find nothing inside. Black Christmas, definitely.
